chat_history.content: : Welcome to Conceptual Academy! I'm Alia, and I'm here to support the learning of core science concepts. Let's get started. How can I help you today?
: Hi Alia. I'm taking a general chemistry course and we're starting a section on molecular polarity. I've always struggled with science topics, so I'm feeling a bit nervous about this chapter.

: I understand your concerns. Many students find chemistry challenging at first, but I think you'll find molecular polarity quite interesting because it helps explain many everyday phenomena. Would you like to explore this topic together?
: Yes, that would be great. I've heard terms like "polar" and "nonpolar" before, but I'm not really sure what they mean in chemistry.

: Let's start with the basics. When all the bonds in a molecule are nonpolar, the molecule as a whole is also nonpolar—as is the case with H₂, O₂, and N₂. When a molecule consists of only two atoms and the bond between them is polar, the polarity of the molecule is the same as the polarity of the bond—as with HF and HCl.
: OK, so if a bond is polar, then a two-atom molecule will always be polar. But what about molecules with more than two atoms? That seems like it could get complicated.

: You've identified an important point. Complexities do arise when assessing the polarity of a molecule containing more than two atoms. Let's consider carbon dioxide, CO₂, as an example.

In CO₂, the cause of the dipole in either of the carbon–oxygen bonds is oxygen's greater pull on the bonding electrons because oxygen is more electronegative than carbon. At the same time, however, the oxygen atom on the opposite side of the carbon pulls those electrons back to the carbon.
: So there's a tug-of-war going on with the electrons?

: That's an excellent way to think about it! The net result is an even distribution of bonding electrons around the entire molecule. Dipoles that are of equal strength but pull in opposite directions in a molecule effectively cancel each other, with the result that the molecule as a whole is nonpolar.

It's analogous to two people in a tug-of-war. As long as they pull with equal force but in opposite directions, the rope remains stationary.
: I think I get it. So even though the individual C-O bonds are polar, the molecule as a whole isn't polar because the "tugs" balance out?

: Precisely! Let's look at another example: boron trifluoride, BF₃. In this molecule, three fluorine atoms are oriented 120° from one another around a central boron atom. Because the angles are all the same and because each fluorine atom pulls on the electrons of its boron–fluorine bond with the same force, the resulting polarity of this molecule is zero.
: So it's like having three people pulling on ropes instead of two?

: Exactly! This is analogous to three people pulling with equal force on ropes attached to a central ring. As long as they all pull with equal force and all maintain the 120° angles, the ring will remain stationary.
: I'm curious - does it matter if a molecule is polar or nonpolar? Does it affect how the substance behaves?

: That's an excellent question! It absolutely matters. Nonpolar molecules have only relatively weak attractions to other nonpolar molecules. This lack of attraction between nonpolar molecules explains the low boiling points of many nonpolar substances.
: Wait, so there's a connection between polarity and boiling points? I never thought of that.

: Yes! Recall that boiling is a process wherein the molecules of a liquid separate from one another as they go into the gaseous phase. When there are only weak attractions between the molecules of a liquid, less heat energy is required to liberate the molecules from one another and allow them to enter the gaseous phase.

This translates into a relatively low boiling point for the liquid. For example, nitrogen (N₂) has a very low boiling point of –196°C. The boiling points of hydrogen (H₂), oxygen (O₂), carbon dioxide (CO₂), and boron trifluoride (BF₃) are also quite low for the same reason.
: Oh, so nonpolar molecules don't stick together very well, which makes them easier to boil. That makes sense. But what about polar molecules? Do they behave differently?

: Yes, they do! But before we get to that, I should mention that polar interactions between molecules are many times weaker than the attractions between ions within an ionic bond. The polar attractions and the ionic bonds are both electrical attractions. The main difference between them is one of magnitude.

Now, let's explore when molecules become polar. There are many instances in which the dipoles of different bonds in a molecule do not cancel each other.
: Is it like our tug-of-war example, but where one person pulls harder than the others?

: That's a great way to visualize it! Reconsider the rope analogy we discussed with the BF₃ molecule. As long as everyone pulls equally, the ring stays put. Imagine, however, that one person begins to ease off on the rope. Now the pulls are no longer balanced, and the ring begins to move away from the person who is slacking off. Likewise, if one person began to pull harder, the ring would move away from the other two people.
: I think I'm starting to understand. So a molecule becomes polar when the electron-pulling isn't balanced?

: Correct! A similar situation occurs in molecules in which polar covalent bonds are not equal and opposite. Perhaps the most relevant example is water, H₂O. Each hydrogen–oxygen covalent bond has a relatively large dipole because of the great electronegativity difference. Because of the bent shape of the molecule, however, the two dipoles do not cancel each other the way the C–O dipoles in CO₂ do.
: So water is a polar molecule? That seems important since water is everywhere.

: Indeed! In water, the dipoles work together to give an overall dipole for the molecule. The region around the oxygen atom is therefore slightly negative, and the region around the two hydrogen atoms is slightly positive.

: This is starting to make more sense. I think I can see how the shape of the molecule affects whether it's polar or not. But I'm still not sure if I could identify which molecules are polar and which aren't.

: Let's practice with a concept check. Which of these two molecules would be polar, and which would be nonpolar?

[Showing the two molecular structures from the concept check in the textbook]
: Hmm, I'm not sure. Let me think... The one on the left looks more symmetrical, so maybe it's nonpolar? And the one on the right looks more uneven, so it might be polar?

: That's excellent reasoning! Symmetry is often the greatest clue for determining polarity. Because the molecule on the left is symmetrical, the dipoles on the two sides cancel each other. This molecule is therefore nonpolar.

Because the molecule on the right is less symmetrical (more "lopsided"), it is a polar molecule.
: That wasn't as hard as I thought! So symmetrical molecules tend to be nonpolar, and asymmetrical ones tend to be polar?

: That's a good rule of thumb, though we always need to consider the specific bonds and electronegativity differences. Now, let's discuss how polarity affects molecular interactions.

Polar molecules electrically attract one another and, as a result, are relatively difficult to separate. In other words, polar molecules can be thought of as being "sticky," which is why it takes more energy to separate them—to change the substance's phase.
: So that's why some liquids boil at much higher temperatures than others?

: Exactly! For this reason, substances composed of polar molecules typically have higher boiling points than substances composed of nonpolar molecules. Water, for example, boils at 100°C, whereas carbon dioxide boils at –79°C. This 179°C difference is quite dramatic when you consider that a carbon dioxide molecule is more than twice as massive as a water molecule.
: Wow, that is a big difference! I've never thought about why water boils at the temperature it does. It's interesting that it's because the molecules are "sticky."

: Yes, water molecules attract one another because each contains a slightly positive side and a slightly negative side. The molecules position themselves in such a way that the positive side of one faces the negative side of a neighbor.
: Is this why oil and water don't mix? I've always wondered about that.

: That's a great connection! Because molecular "stickiness" can play a lead role in determining a substance's macroscopic properties, molecular polarity is a central concept of chemistry.

It's not, however, that oil and water repel each other. Rather, water molecules are so attracted to themselves because of their polarity that they pull themselves together. The nonpolar oil molecules are thus excluded and left to themselves.
: Oh, I see! Like when you shake up oil and vinegar salad dressing, but then they separate again?

: Precisely! We see this in a bottle of oil and vinegar salad dressing. After the bottle is shaken vigorously, the water molecules of the vinegar cling together, excluding the oil molecules, which separate into their own layer. Being less dense than water, the oil rises to the top.

The same principle was sadly evident in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill of 2010 in the Gulf of Mexico—the largest accidental oil spill in human history. The oil came from a seafloor oil gusher that released an estimated 53,000 barrels every day for three months before it was finally capped. Petroleum-based oil molecules are not able to compete with the attraction water molecules have for themselves, which is why the oil and water don't mix.
: I remember seeing those terrible images. I never realized the chemistry behind why the oil stayed separate from the water.

: It shows how understanding molecular concepts can help us understand large-scale phenomena in our world. The shape of a molecule, as determined by VSEPR, plays a major role in determining the polarity of that molecule. A molecule's polarity, in turn, has a great influence on macroscopic behavior.
: So the shape affects the polarity, which affects how substances behave. It's all connected!

: Yes, it all connects! Consider what the world would be like if the oxygen atom in a water molecule did not have its two nonbonding pairs of electrons. Instead of being bent, each water molecule would be linear, much like carbon dioxide. The dipoles of the two hydrogen–oxygen bonds would cancel each other, which would make water a nonpolar substance and give it a relatively low boiling point.
: So water wouldn't be a liquid at normal temperatures?

: That's right! Water would not be a liquid at the ambient temperatures of our planet, and we in turn would not be here discussing these concepts. We should be thankful that the oxygen within water has two nonbonding pairs. That's good chemistry.
: I never thought about it that way before. So all life on Earth depends on water having those nonbonding pairs and being polar?
: Absolutely. All species on our planet depend upon water, H₂O, for survival. The polarity of water molecules is fundamental to how water functions in our bodies and in our environment.
: This has been really helpful, Alia. Chemistry is starting to make more sense to me now. I can see how these molecular concepts actually explain things I see in the real world.
: I'm glad to hear that! Understanding molecular polarity gives us insights into many aspects of the world around us. Is there anything else about this topic you'd like to explore?
: Not right now. I think I need to digest what we've covered before moving on. But I feel much more confident about this chapter now. Thanks for your help!

: You're very welcome! You've made excellent progress today. Remember that connecting scientific concepts to the world around you is one of the best ways to deepen your understanding. Please feel free to return anytime you have questions about this or other science topics.
